title-group.article-title: Evc Regulates a Symmetrical Response to Shh Signaling in Molar Development

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Genetic Medicine, Newcastle University, International Centre for Life, Central Parkway, Newcastle upon Tyne, NE1 3BZ, UK

2present address, Division of Anatomy and Cell Biology of the Hard Tissue, Department of Tissue Regeneration and Reconstruction, Niigata University Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, 2-5274, Gakkocho-dori, Chuo-ku, Niigata, Japan

abstract.p: Tooth morphogenesis involves patterning through the activity of epithelial signaling centers that, among other molecules, secrete Sonic hedgehog (Shh). While it is known that Shh responding cells need intact primary cilia for signal transduction, the roles of individual cilia components for tooth morphogenesis are poorly understood. The clinical features of individuals with Ellis-van Creveld syndrome include various dental anomalies, and we show here that absence of the cilial protein Evc in mice causes various hypo- and hyperplasia defects during molar development. During first molar development, the response to Shh signaling is progressively lost in Evc-deficient embryos and, unexpectedly, the response consistently disappears in a buccal to lingual direction. The important role of Evc for establishing the buccal-lingual axis of the developing first molar is also supported by a displaced activity of the Wnt pathway in Evc mutants. The observed growth abnormalities eventually manifest in first molar microdontia, disruption of molar segmentation and symmetry, root fusions, and delayed differentiation. Analysis of our data indicates that both spatially and temporally disrupted activities of the Shh pathway are the primary cause for the variable dental anomalies seen in patients with Ellis-van Creveld syndrome or Weyers acrodental dysostosis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Epithelial-mesenchymal interactions regulate inductive events throughout tooth development (Jernvall and Thesleff, 2000; Tucker and Sharpe, 2004). In mice, expression of Sonic hedgehog (Shh) is detectable in the dental epithelium from embryonic day 11.0 (E11.0; Bitgood and McMahon, 1995), and at E14.5 a highly localized expression is seen in the enamel knots, which act as epithelial signaling centers (Vaahtokari et al., 1996). At later stages, Shh expression is seen in growing roots and during ameloblast renewal and differentiation (Gritli-Linde et al., 2002; Nakatomi et al., 2006). In signal-receiving cells, secreted Shh protein binds to the receptor Patched1 (Ptch1), thereby activating Smoothened (Smo), a transmembrane protein that is inhibited by Ptch1 in the absence of Shh. Smo in turn prevents proteolytic processing of the transcription factor Gli3 into its repressor form. This promotes the generation of Gli(1-3) activators that ultimately regulate the transcription of Shh pathway downstream genes, which include Ptch1 and Gli1 (Ingham et al., 2011).

Shh regulates growth and morphogenesis of the developing teeth (Dassule et al., 2000), and this pathway requires intact primary cilia, organelles which project from the cell surface as small, rod-shaped structures (Huangfu et al., 2003; Goetz and Anderson, 2010). Cilia formation and maintenance require mobilization of proteins toward the tip and base of cilia along the microtubule-based axoneme by anterograde and retrograde intraflagellar transport (IFT) complexes, respectively (Silverman and Leroux, 2009). IFT acts downstream of Ptch1 and Smo, and one of its components, polaris, was shown to restrict the Shh pathway in tooth development (Ohazama et al., 2009).

Ellis-van Creveld (EvC) syndrome (OMIM #225500) is an autosomal-recessive disorder characterized by chondrodysplasia, polydactyly, nail dysplasia, and cardiac defects (Ellis and van Creveld, 1940). The remarkably variable dental anomalies of EvC patients include prenatal or delayed tooth eruption, hypodontia, conical teeth, taurodontism, micro/macrodontia, and enamel hypoplasia (Mostafa et al., 2005). Mutations in EVC and EVC2, 2 genes arranged in a head-to-head configuration and both encoding proteins with coiled-coil domains, were shown to underlie EvC (Ruiz-Perez et al., 2003). Evc and Evc2 interact with each other and localize to primary cilia in co-transfected cells, while individually expressed proteins do not (Blair et al., 2011). Gene inactivation of Evc, Evc2, or both, in mice does not affect cilia formation but mimics key features of chondrodysplasia phenotypes seen in Ellis-van Creveld syndrome patients, due to a defective response to Indian hedgehog (Ihh), a homolog of Shh (Ruiz-Perez et al., 2007; Caparros-Martin et al., 2013). In this work, we investigated Evc functions during odontogenesis, focusing on mouse molar development.

sec.title: Mice
sec.p: Generation and genotyping of Evc knockout mice maintained on a C57BL/6 background have been reported (Ruiz-Perez et al., 2007). The day of vaginal plug detection was counted as embryonic day 0.5 (E 0.5). All experimental procedures were approved by the Newcastle University Local Ethics Committee and by the Home Office (UK).

sec.title: Staining Procedures, in situ Hybridization, and Immunohistochemistry
sec.p: Bone staining of animals at post-natal day 28 (P28) was carried out as previously described (Iseki et al., 1997). For hematoxylin/eosin staining and in situ hybridization, specimens were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde. Post-natal samples were decalcified with Morse’s solution as previously described (Nakatomi et al., 2006). For cell proliferation assays, 5-bromo-2′-deoxy-uridine (BrdU) (Roche, Indianapolis, IN, USA) dissolved in phosphate-buffered saline was intraperitoneally injected into pregnant mice (100 µg/g body weight) 2 hrs before embryo dissection and fixation with Bouin’s fixative. All specimens were dehydrated through an ethanol series, embedded in paraffin, and sectioned at 5 µm. Whole-mount and section in situ hybridization and anti-BrdU and anti-Shh immunohistochemistry were performed as previously described (Gritli-Linde et al., 2001; Nakatomi et al., 2010). The percentage of BrdU-positive cells was calculated from 30 epithelial cells in each of 3 different compartments of the first molar (8 sections for each genotype), and data were analyzed by Student’s t test. Digoxigenin-labeled RNA probes for Ameloblastin, Dentin sialoprotein, Evc, Evc2, Fgf4, Gli1, Lef1, Ptch1, Pax9, Shh, and Wnt10b (details available on request) were generated according to the manufacturer’s protocol (Roche).

sec.title: Computer-aided 3D Reconstructions
sec.p: After fixation in Bouin’s fluid, mouse embryonic heads were embedded in paraffin, cut in series of 7-µm frontal sections, and stained with hematoxylin/eosin and alcian blue. The epithelium of the right upper molar area was reconstructed in 7 series of routinely stained frontal paraffin sections from E13.5-E15.5. Protocols for 3D reconstruction were applied as previously described (Lesot et al., 1996; Hovorakova et al., 2011).

sec.title: Morphological and Occlusal Defects of Evc-deficient Dentition
sec.p: The murine dentition consists of 3 molars and 1 incisor per quadrant. While all teeth were present in adult Evc-/- mice, they exhibited abnormal patterning, morphogenesis, and differentiation. Consistent with an overall growth retardation of Evc-/- mice, the lower jaws were smaller; however, lower incisor growth was disproportionately retarded, as indicated by the cervical loop position (Fig. 1B). In addition, all mutant incisors were hypoplastic and showed rounded tips, which was accompanied with a misalignment of upper and lower incisors (Fig. 1D).

caption.p: Dental abnormalities of adult Evc mutants. The anterior side is to the left, and genotypes are indicated in all panels. (A, B) Lingual view of the right mandible (P28). The posterior end of the incisor is behind the third molar in wild-type mice (dotted line in A), while in the mutants it is located at the level of the diastema region (dotted line in B). (C, D) Upper and lower incisors stained with Alizarin red. Note the hypoplasia and round tips of both incisors (arrows) and the outward direction of the upper incisor in the mutant. (E, F) Lingual view of the right molars. The upper first and second molars are fused (M1+M2), and the lower first molar is smaller than the second molar in mutants (F). (G, H) Oral view of the right half of secondary palate and upper molars. Rugae are numbered from anterior to posterior, and molar sizes are indicated. The anterior margin of the first molar (dotted line) indicates that the molar field is shifted posteriorly. (I-N) Extracted lower first (I, J), second (K, L), and third (M, N) molars. Note the significantly reduced size and single-rooted mutant first molar (J). The latter phenotype can also be seen in the mutant second molar (L). LI, lower incisor; M1, first molar; M2, second molar; M3, third molar; M1+2, fused first and second molars; UI, upper incisor.

sec.p: Fusions of first and second molars were regularly observed in the Evc mutant maxilla (100% penetrance; N = 6) and occasionally occurred in the mandible (17% penetrance; N = 6) (Figs. 1F, 1H). In addition, whereas wild-type molars were arranged in so-called “cusp to ridge” or “1 tooth to 2 teeth” occlusal contacts (Fig. 1E), the lower first and the upper third molars of Evc mutant mice lacked their occlusal counterparts (Fig. 1F). Alignment with the positions of the rugae of the secondary palate revealed that the anterior margin of the wild-type first molar was located between the third and fourth rugae (Fig. 1G). In contrast, in mutant first molars this margin was found between the fourth and fifth rugae (Fig. 1H), suggesting that the posterior shift of upper molars is the main cause for the occlusal defect.

The size of first molars in adult Evc mutant mice was drastically reduced (Figs. 1I, 1J). Moreover, fewer and malformed cusps were present in mutant first molars, and only a single root was formed. Surprisingly, whereas the mutant second molar also developed one root, its overall tooth crown size was similar to that of wild-type mice (Figs. 1K, 1L). The Evc mutant third molar did not show obvious abnormalities (Figs. 1M, 1N).

sec.title: Unbalanced Development of the First and Second Molars of Evc Mutants
sec.p: Patterning and morphogenesis of the mouse molars have been extensively studied, and we therefore focused on this tooth type for further analyses. 3D reconstructions revealed that the anterior part of the dental epithelium was slightly enlarged in Evc mutants at E13.5 (Figs. 2A, 2D). At E14.5, the buccal half of the dental epithelium was hypoplastic, while the lingual half was hyperplastic and posteriorly extended. A thickened epithelium posterior to the first molar indicated a prematurely developing second molar (Figs. 2B, 2E). The unbalanced progression of first and second molars was also present in the lower dentition at E15.5 (Figs. 2C, 2F) and was obvious at E17.5 (Figs. 2G-2J). Moreover, a distinct separation between first and second molar fields was missing in Evc mutants (Figs. 2F, 2J), in line with regularly observed molar fusions.

caption.p: Molar development in Evc mutant embryos is mainly affected on the buccal side. Genotypes are specified in all panels, and anterior-posterior or buccal-lingual orientations are indicated for each set. (A-F) 3D reconstructions of upper molars. (A, D) Tooth formation is similar between wild-type and mutant embryos at E13.5, except for an increased size of the anterior rudimentary epithelium (arrow; also see insets). (B, E) The first molar is smaller and the buccal epithelium (arrowhead) is hypoplastic in the mutant at E14.5. Note also that second molar development is initiated earlier compared with the control sample (arrow). (C, F) First and second molars are clearly separated in wild-type embryos and are fused in the mutant at E15.5 (arrow). (G,H) Sagittal and (I,J) coronal sections of the lower molars at E17.5 showing that the first molar is smaller than the second molar also in the lower molar field of Evc mutants. (K-N) Frontal sections of the lower first molar. (K,L) At E18.5, the buccal cervical loop is hypoplastic in mutants (arrowhead), while the lingual cervical loop has formed (arrow). (M,N) The adult (P28) mutant first molar is hypoplastic, and the lingual Hertwig’s epithelial root sheath has grown toward the buccal side (arrow). In addition, the lower incisor is missing at this level, and the area occupied by trabecular bone is widely expanded. (O-R) Sections of the second molar at corresponding stages show that this tooth is less affected. A, anterior; B, bone; bu, buccal; D, dentin; DP, dental pulp; LI, lower incisor; li, lingual; M1, first molar; M2, second molar; MN, mandibular nerve; p, posterior; R, rudimentary tooth bud; TB, trabecular bone. Scale bars: 500 µm in (M); otherwise 100 µm.

sec.p: Histological staining of frontal sections at E18.5 revealed a symmetry defect of the lower first molar epithelium with respect to the buccal-lingual axis. Similar to the upper molars, the buccal aspect of the dental epithelium was also clearly hypoplastic in lower molars (Figs. 2K, 2L). The unbalanced growth eventually manifested in a stunted first molar with a significantly underdeveloped root and a small dental papilla (Figs. 2M, 2N). In contrast, while the size of the second molar of Evc mutants was slightly increased relative to the first molars, its overall morphology did not differ from that of wild-type mice (Figs. 2O-2R).

sec.title: Evc Deficiency Causes Local Disruptions of the Shh Downstream Pathway
sec.p: At E12.5 and E13.5, stages that precede noticeable defects in first molar symmetry, Evc mRNA was expressed symmetrically in both dental epithelium and mesenchyme. Subsequently, Evc and Evc2 were expressed in the inner and outer enamel epithelium, dental mesenchyme, and dental follicle of the developing lower first molar at E15.5 and E17.5 (Appendix Fig. 1 and data not shown), thus overlapping with the expression of Ptch1 and Gli1 (Dassule et al., 2000; Gritli-Linde et al., 2002). In Evc mutants, Shh mRNA and protein expression was detectable at normal levels during first molar development (Figs. 3A, 3B, 3I-3P, Appendix Fig. 2), whereas expression of Shh downstream targets was affected in a remarkably dynamic manner. The mesenchymal expression of Ptch1 and Gli1 was missing in cells adjacent to the epithelial bud at E13.0 (Figs. 3C-3F), while the normal expression of Pax9 (Neubüser et al., 1997) indicated that the dental mesenchyme was correctly specified in Evc mutants (Figs. 3G, 3H). At E14.5 and E15.5, Ptch1 transcripts were detectable only in the lingual half of the Evc mutant molar primordium (Figs. 3R, 3T), and the expression was subsequently lost from E17.5 to P0 (Figs. 3V, 3X).

caption.p: The response to Shh signaling is successively lost in a buccal to lingual direction in the developing first lower molars of Evc mutants. (A,B) Whole-mount and (C-X) frontal section in situ hybridization. Genotypes and embryonic stages are indicated for all panels, and buccal is to the left (C-X). (A,B) In the Evc-deficient E12.5 lower mandible, Shh expression was detectable in the incisors and in the molar field (arrows). At the early bud stage, Ptch1 (C,D) and Gli1 (E,F) expression was reduced in the mesenchyme of Evc mutants (arrows), while Pax9 (G,H) was expressed normally. (I,J) In the E14.5 mutant, the buccal epithelium was growth-retarded (arrow), and the Shh expression domain was buccally shifted. (K-P) Between E15.5 and P0, Shh expression was maintained in the inner enamel epithelium of the mutants. (Q,R) The buccal expression domain of Ptch1 is lost in the mutant at E14.5 (arrow). (S-X) Between E15.5 and P0, Ptch1 expression gradually disappears at the lingual side. AM, ameloblasts; bu, buccal; DE, dental epithelium; DM, dental mesenchyme; EK, enamel knot; IN, incisors; li, lingual; OD, odontoblasts; TO, tongue. Scale bars: 1 mm (A,B); 50 µm (C-H, I-L, Q-T); 100 µm (M-P, U-X).

sec.p: While the levels of Shh mRNA remained robust in the dental epithelium of Evc mutants (Figs. 3I-3P), the expression domains of Shh and Wnt10b indicated a buccal shift of the primary enamel knot (Fig. 3J; Figs. 4E, 4F). Similarly, the expression of Lef1, a Wnt-signaling effector gene, was buccally expanded in both epithelium and mesenchyme (Figs. 4A-4F). At E15.5 and E17.5, Lef1 expression was aberrantly up-regulated in the inner enamel epithelium and continued to be expressed in a broad area of the dental mesenchyme. In contrast, Fgf4 expression appeared normal at E14.5 and was lingually expanded at E15.5 (Figs. 4G-4N). Fgf4 and Wnt pathways are both known to regulate epithelial morphogenesis during tooth development (Jernvall et al., 1994; Liu et al., 2008). Their de-regulated expression may contribute to the dental abnormalities of Evc mutants, as seen, for example, in the lingual cervical loop epithelium in one Evc-deficient upper molar (Appendix Fig. 2).

caption.p: Altered expression of enamel knot markers and proliferation defects in the Evc mutant dental epithelium. (A-N; X,Y) In situ hybridization and (O-V) BrdU immunohistochemistry on frontal sections. Genotypes and developmental stages are indicated for all panels, and buccal is to the left. (A,B) The position of the Fgf4 expression domain was not altered in Evc mutants at E14.5, while the epithelial expression of Lef1 (C,D) and Wnt10b (E,F) was shifted to the buccal side (arrowheads). Lef1 expression was also up-regulated in the buccal mesenchyme (arrow). (G,H) At E15.5, Fgf4 expression was expanded lingually, and (I,J) Lef1 expression remained up-regulated. (K,L) At E17.5, Fgf4 expression in the mutant marks the position of a buccal secondary enamel knot (the lingual cusp was not present on this section but appeared on adjacent section; data not shown). (M,N) Lef1 expression in the epithelium indicated the positions of secondary enamel knots in the Evc mutant (arrowheads) and continued in the mesenchyme adjacent to the hypoplastic buccal cervical loop (arrow). (O-R) Representative sections showing strongly reduced proliferation of epithelial cells in the central region of the first molar (arrows). (S,T) In the buccal cervical loop of Evc mutants, the inner enamel epithelial cells are not aligned (arrow), and outer enamel epithelial cells are cuboidal (arrowhead) rather than flat and elongated. (U,V) In the lingual cervical loop of Evc mutants, the inner enamel epithelial cells are aligned, but outer enamel epithelial cells are cuboidal (arrowhead). (W) Summary of proliferation assay at E15.5 (see Appendix Table for raw data). Proliferation is strongly affected (76.5% reduction) in the central region of the inner enamel epithelium. (X,Y) The expression of Ambn is reduced in the buccal cusp region of mutants at P0 (arrowhead). IEE, inner enamel epithelium; OEE, outer enamel epithelium. Scale bars: 50 µm (A-J; O,P; S-V); 100 µm (K-N; Q-R;X,Y).

sec.title: Local Cell Proliferation and Differentiation Defects in the First Molars of Evc Mutants
sec.p: Cells of the primary enamel knot secrete growth factors that induce cell proliferation in adjacent cells but not in the enamel knot itself (Jernvall et al., 1994). Interestingly, BrdU labeling experiments indicate that this proliferation pattern is abnormally maintained after the cap stage of first molar development of Evc mutant mice. At E15.5, proliferation of inner enamel epithelial cells situated between the cervical loops resumes after the enamel knot has disappeared but was reduced by more than 75% (p < 0.0001) in Evc mutants. In contrast, the difference in the buccal cervical loop was less significant (31% reduction; p = 0.014) and was negligible in the lingual cervical loop (4% reduction, p = 0.753). Strongly reduced numbers of BrdU-positive cells in the central compartment of the inner enamel epithelium were also evident at E17.5 (Figs. 4O-4R, 4W).

While proliferation was not strongly affected in the cervical loops of Evc mutants, the epithelial architecture was affected at E17.5. In Evc mutants, clusters of non-aligned epithelial cells were found next to the buccal cervical loop, and cells of the outer enamel epithelium were cuboidal in both cervical loops (Figs. 4S-4V). Finally, the ameloblast and odontoblast differentiation markers Ameloblastin (Ambn) and Dentin sialoprotein (Dsp), respectively, were expressed in the lingual half of the first molar at P0, while the buccal expression appeared at later stages in Evc mutants (Figs. 4X,4Y; data not shown).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Evc-/- mice exhibit dental hypoplasia, first and second molar fusion, and abnormal root development. Similar defects have been described in mice lacking Shh or Smo in the dental epithelium (Dassule et al., 2000; Gritli-Linde et al., 2002), and mild root abnormalities have been found in mice expressing a mutant form of Ptch1 (Nakatomi et al., 2006). A role for Shh in regulating tooth morphogenesis along the buccal-lingual axis has been suggested; however, while the absence of Shh was shown to cause growth retardation in the lingual epithelium (Dassule et al., 2000), first molar development in Evc mutants was arrested primarily at the buccal half. These contrasting results remain elusive at present, especially since Evc is expressed in both buccal and lingual halves during molar development. While recent studies showed that the Evc/Evc2 complex interacts with Smo and regulates Sufu/Gli3 dissociation and Gli3 trafficking in primary cilia (Caparrós-Martín et al., 2013; Dorn et al., 2012; Yang et al., 2012), the gradual loss of Ptch1 expression along the buccal-lingual axis in Evc mutants may indicate that maintenance of Shh response in the buccal half requires Evc functions at an earlier time-point. Alternatively, Evc could be involved in suppressing a developmental pathway that antagonizes Shh signaling in the buccal half. Finally, the increased requirement of Evc in the buccal epithelium may also be related to a suggested dual origin of the dental epithelium: an ectodermally derived buccal half and an endodermally derived lingual half (Imai et al., 1998). It is interesting to note that developmental defects in organs derived from the endoderm have not been identified in Evc-deficient mice (Ruiz-Perez et al., 2007).

At the cap stage, the unbalanced activation of Shh signaling in Evc mutants is associated with a buccal expansion of the expression domains of Shh, Wnt10b, and Lef1. In contrast, expression of Fgf4 appeared highly localized at this stage, suggesting that a functional Shh pathway regulates the positioning of some, but not all, enamel knot markers. Shh-, Wnt10b-, and Fgf4-expressing cells are spatially displaced in Evc mutants which could, at least in part, be responsible for the proliferation defects at E15.5 and E17.5. Indeed, proliferation was not particularly affected in the growth-retarded, buccal cervical loop of Evc mutants but was drastically reduced in the central inner enamel epithelium. Moreover, the expansion and up-regulation of Lef1 expression in Evc mutants suggest that Evc could be involved in integrating Shh and the canonical Wnt pathways, the latter found to be up-regulated in some embryonic tissues with impaired cilia functions (Gerdes et al., 2007; Corbit et al., 2008).

Interestingly, while the morphogenesis of the first molar is strongly affected in Evc mutants, the second molar develops precociously, and its embryonic size exceeds that of control second molars. Whereas we cannot rule out a direct role of Evc in regulating second molar size, this defect could also result secondarily to a suppressed inhibitory capacity of the first molar, which is known to regulate the size of the second molar field (Kavanagh et al., 2007). Notably, despite its normal size, Evc-deficient second molars form a single root only, and further analyses of Evc mutants may help to elucidate the role of Shh signaling for root patterning. In summary, our results show that Evc is required for a spatially balanced Shh pathway activation during molar development. Similar disruptions of the Shh pathway, combined with displaced Wnt signaling, are therefore likely to underlie the dental defects associated with the human conditions EvC syndrome and Weyers acrodental dysostosis.

ack.p: We thank Drs. P.H. Krebsbach for Ambn, H.H. Ritchie for Dsp, A. Joyner for Gli1, M. Scott for Ptch1, A.P. McMahon for Shh, and J. Wang for Wnt10b riboprobes.

A supplemental appendix to this article is published electronically only at http://jdr.sagepub.com/supplemental.
